tangamanga.title: Tangamanga Park I
tangamanga.subtitle: Mexico's Second Largest Urban Park - Where Nature Meets Adventure

history.title: History & Cultural Significance
history.meaningText: The name "Tangamanga" comes from the Huachichil language, an indigenous group that once inhabited the region. It translates to "meeting place" or "place of gathering", reflecting the park's role as a central social and cultural hub for the community.
history.originText: The park was formed on the grounds of the old Hacienda de la Tenería, which dates back to 1609. The hacienda's main building is still preserved within the park, serving as a silent witness to over four centuries of Potosino history.
history.creationText: The project's first phase began in 1982, when the land was expropriated and over a thousand trees were planted. The park was officially inaugurated in 1983 during the government of Prof. Carlos Jonguitud Barrios. In 1997, the government gave it the official name "Parque Carlos Jonguitud Barrios", although most people simply know it as Tangamanga Park.
history.impactText: With an area of 420 hectares, Tangamanga Park I is positioned as the second largest urban park in Mexico, only surpassed by Bosque de Chapultepec in Mexico City, and one of the largest urban parks in the world. Its more than 1.8 million trees make it the most important green lung of San Luis Potosí, producing 800 tons of oxygen per year.

attractions.title: Main Attractions
attractions.natural1: Botanical garden with endemic and exotic species
attractions.natural3: Walking and cycling trails over 10 km long
attractions.cultural1: Zoo with native and exotic species
attractions.cultural4: Tangamanga EcoMuseum in historic tannery buildings
attractions.cultural5: Teatro Carlos Amador for concerts and events
attractions.cultural6: Tangamanga Splash - water park with slides and pools

biodiversity.title: Biodiversity & Nature
biodiversity.text: The park hosts an extraordinary diversity of flora and fauna. In its 420 hectares, more than 1.8 million native and exotic trees coexist, along with migratory and resident birds, as well as small mammals and reptiles. The botanical garden is especially important for the conservation of endemic species from the Potosino region and the Mexican desert.

sustainability.title: Self-Sustainability
sustainability.description: Tangamanga Park is a model of environmental sustainability
sustainability.feature1Text: Water treatment plants that allow water reuse for irrigation of all green areas
sustainability.feature2Text: Own production of organic compost to nourish the park's vegetation
sustainability.feature3Text: Generation of 800 tons of oxygen per year thanks to its 1.8 million trees

tips.title: Visitor Tips
tips.tip1: Bring sunscreen, hat, and plenty of water
tips.tip2: Wear comfortable shoes for walking - the park is very large
tips.tip3: Arrive early on weekends to find good parking
tips.tip4: Check the Teatro Carlos Amador event calendar
tips.tip5: Visit the EcoMuseum to learn about the Hacienda de la Tenería history
tips.tip6: The park closes Monday afternoons - plan your visit accordingly
tips.tip8: Don't leave trash - help keep the city's green lung clean
